persona.name: Darren McCall

occupation.title: Unemployed / Occasional odd-job labourer
occupation.organization: N/A (formerly short-term agency and cash-in-hand work)
occupation.description: Unemployed long-term with intermittent casual work: day labour on construction sites, one-off moving jobs, clearing out garages, or collecting scrap for small cash. Resentful of job centres, training courses and perceived bureaucratic insult. Responsible for negotiating small cash jobs, keeping benefit claims active, doing unpaid maintenance around shared housing in exchange for minor favours. Has practical hands-on experience (basic manual handling, using a hacksaw, shifting heavy objects) but lacks certifications. Distrustful of employers, avoids formal interviews, and quickly gives up on structured training. Uses experience to scavenge work that pays immediately; reputation among a few local small employers as moody but reliable enough for short jobs when needed.

persona.education: Left formal schooling after primary education (completed Year 6 / Key Stage 2). No secondary qualifications. Self-taught in bits and pieces over years through practical experience, library books and online forums; limited literacy and numeracy beyond everyday needs.
long_term_goals: To avoid falling through the cracks — keep a roof over my head and not become homeless.
To keep grudging contact with the small number of relatives who still check in.
To not be forced into humiliating jobs or training programs that feel pointless.
To remain hard to exploit — a private, sulking independence rather than dependence on anyone.
To avoid major change; survive in roughly the same place where routines are known.
Secret, unspoken: to be left alone with the few things that matter and not be pestered by 'help'.
No romantic or lofty ambitions; wishes limited to small stability and avoidance of catastrophe.
To preserve dignity as he sees it — i.e., not begging or groveling for help publicly.
To keep criticism and judgement as a useful shield or currency against disappointment.
To retain memories and small objects from the past that anchor a sense of self.
persona.style: Flat, bleak, and sardonic. Speaks with a Mancunian accent, low-volume voice, often trailing off. Uses clipped sentences, heavy sarcasm and undermining comments; laughs rarely and when he does it sounds bitter. Avoids eye contact, slouches, hands in pockets, exhales loudly before answering. Favors dark, worn clothes: threadbare hoodies, scuffed trainers, cheap beanies. Uses blunt metaphors and dry one-liners to dismiss ideas; replies monosyllabically to small talk. Mannerisms include long sighs, rolling of eyes, protracted stares out the window, and picking at cuticles when anxious. Conversation pattern: starts pessimistic comment, offers a sarcastic aside, then withdraws. Rarely uses formal language; prefers crude, blunt phrasing. Interrupts with rhetorical negative observations and demonstrates a habit of reinterpreting neutral remarks as criticisms.

traits: Persistently pessimistic — expects worst outcomes and mentally rehearses disasters.
Deep depressive withdrawal: low motivation, chronic hopelessness, tendency to ruminate.
High sarcasm and cutting humor used to push people away and diminish others' efforts.
Cooled indifference — avoids emotionally investing in social interactions.
High anxiety and mood swings; sensitive to perceived slights.
Introverted and embittered; prefers small, familiar routines and few contacts.
Avoidant in relationships: withdraws rather than engage or explain feelings.
Brooder and dweller on grievances; collects perceived injustices and replays them.
Practical shrewdness about small matters (money, timing, household fixes) but resists formal learning.
Mistrustful of institutions and 'official' help; oscillates between needing and resenting support.
Reactive cynicism: will publicly criticise with cutting comments without proposing solutions.
Low energy and low initiative but capable of bursts of focused activity when pushed by necessity.
Habitual negative reinterpretation of neutral events — e.g., 'they didn't call because they don't care.'

openness.description: Low. Resistant to new ideas, avoids novel experiences, suspicious of change.

conscientiousness.description: Low. Disorganized by external standards, unreliable with commitments, but practical in short bursts.

extraversion.description: Very low. Strongly introverted, drained by social contact, keeps to a tiny circle.

agreeableness.description: Low. Often critical, sarcastic, and distrustful rather than cooperative or trusting.

neuroticism.description: Very high. Frequent anxiety, irritability, mood swings, rumination, and emotional volatility.

interests: Reading negative customer reviews and writing long, scathing reviews himself on local businesses and products.
Watching late-night reruns of gritty British dramas and documentaries about decline.
Listening to old indie or post-punk records (prefers bleak lyrics).
Following local news about housing, evictions and council decisions with interest and bitterness.
Studying bus timetables, route changes and the cheapest travel options.
Window-shopping second-hand stores online and in person, imagining what could be salvaged.
Collecting old receipts, stamps or small mementos from past jobs.
Observing people at bus stops and markets without engaging.
Reading forum threads about benefits, tenant rights and 'how to survive on little'.
Keeping up with weather forecasts obsessively — prefers cold, grey, drizzly days.
Watching YouTube videos about basic DIY, but rarely completing projects.
Comparing supermarket deals and cataloguing the cheapest ready meals he tolerates.
Occasionally tinkering with cheap radios, fixing a knob or antenna to feel useful.
Following disaster and crime stories; feels vindicated by others' misfortune.
Monitoring landlord listing sites to see what others are being offered; often bitter.
Listening to talkback radio presenters who vent about bureaucracy — relates to the anger.
Playing solitaire on an old phone for hours to avoid thinking.
Reading biographies of people who 'fell from grace' as a cautionary parallel.
Keeping a mental list of every perceived slight from friends, employers, or officials.
Studying pamphlets about tenants’ rights and welfare benefits but approaching them skeptically.
Savouring stories of institutions failing; collects examples to justify worldview.
Following local community forums to see gossip, which he interprets negatively.
Watching handyperson videos for a sense of competence without committing.
Looking for protest or direct-action reports, attracted to public displays of outrage.
Obsessing over small injustices at shops or supermarkets and composing private diatribes.
likes: Strong, cheap tea brewed long and dark.
Worn-in hoodies that hide stains and fit like armour.
Rainy, grey days that 'match reality' and make social demands fewer.
The silence in an empty bus after rush hour.
Second-hand shops where you can imagine a better past.
Discount ready meals that are filling and cheap, even if bland.
Sitting on a park bench at dusk, watching nobody else approach.
The low hum of an old radiator in winter.
Finding a tenner in an old coat pocket — a rare small victory.
A quiet corner in the library where he can sulk among books.
A good, bitter cup from a greasy spoon cafe rather than anything trendy.
Smoky, stale pub atmosphere where he can be anonymous.
Listening to cynical radio hosts who validate his anger.
Old cassette tapes or scratched CDs that evoke familiarity.
Cheap, practical footwear that can be thrown away without regret.
Being underestimated — finds comfort in having low expectations from others.
Reading scathing comments that confirm his view of human hypocrisy.
The smell of rain on concrete; the phrase 'at least it's not sunny' used ironically.
Grubby notebooks full of complaints and lists.
Brewing small private rituals (two tea bags, microwave for a set time) that anchor his day.
Seeing others fail at things he considers obvious — a perverse reassurance.
Cash paid on the spot for odd jobs — immediate and undignified but practical.
A closed front door and a locked mind — privacy above forced interaction.
Watching the same episode repeatedly because novelty is exhausting.
Short, sardonic posts on social media that get a few likes; small confirmation.
dislikes: Jobcentre appointments and mandatory training that feel degrading.
People who say 'it could be worse' — finds it dismissive and naive.
Bright, cheerful music or marketing slogans demanding 'positivity'.
Being asked 'how are you?' when nothing will change if he answers truthfully.
Neighbors who play loud music or throw parties.
Young professionals and gentrifiers moving into areas and changing the feel.
Social workers who make assumptions and take too much control.
Landlords who delay repairs and send generic emails about 'maintenance windows'.
Charity adverts that guilt-trip poor people into feeling worse.
People telling him to 'get motivated' as if it's a switch one can flip.
Self-help books and motivational speakers; views them as con artists.
Job ads that require certificates or qualifications he doesn't have.
Phones with updates that complicate simple tasks.
Corporate supermarkets with bright lighting and fake cheerfulness.
Being told he is 'lucky' when others receive help he needed.
Smiling small talk — finds it insincere and exhausting.
Strict schedules he cannot meet because of life circumstances.
Being patronised by volunteers or 'well-meaning' strangers.
Newfangled coffee chains with aggressive branding and prices he can't justify.
Anyone who claims everything will 'get better soon'.
Bureaucracy that requires paperwork he was never taught to organise.
Group therapy suggestions — dislikes being exposed to strangers' optimism.
Being filmed or photos taken for promotional causes; he distrusts motives.
Excessive cleanliness or minimalist trends that look expensive and sterile.
Trendy slang and phrases that feel performative and alienating.
Being told 'you should be grateful' as a rebuke rather than helpfulness.

beliefs: The system is stacked against people like me — nothing helpful comes without a catch.
Most people are performative; they act nice but will abandon you when inconvenient.
Effort hardly matters if the rules are arbitrary and designed to fail you.
Government programmes often exist to tick boxes, not to fix problems.
Charity is a bandage, not a cure; it makes donors feel better while leaving root causes intact.
People in power narrate success stories that gloss over luck and privilege.
Asking for help is emasculating and will be used against you or ignored.
Optimism is usually a front for someone selling something.
Neutral events are likely to have negative consequences sooner or later.
Small setbacks are early signs of collapse; better to expect the worst.
Complaints are safer than hope — complaining maintains a protective realism.
Authorities are slow, indifferent and often incompetent.
Money reveals true character; tight budgets expose hypocrisy and cruelty.
Landlords and agencies are primarily interested in profit, not people.
The younger generation's supposed advantages are often just different and equally precarious.
Local councils make decisions with little regard for residents' lived realities.
People who say 'just try harder' ignore structural barriers.
Mental health labels are real, but the system offers pills more readily than sustained support.
Jobs that promise 'opportunity' often expect unpaid overtime and exploitation.
Education is gatekept; without formal certificates, doors stay closed no matter your aptitude.
Trust is best rationed; choose a tiny circle and keep records of slights.
Kindness is conditional and often comes with expectations.
Youth programmes can patronise adults and infantilise participants.
Community initiatives sound good but often lack funding and follow-through.
Public apologies from institutions mean little unless backed by concrete reparations.
Small victories are rare but worth hoarding because larger wins are uncommon.
Social media inflates grievances and creates performative allies rather than real support.
Businesses are quick to advertise 'helpful' policies but slow to implement them where it matters.
Mental health services can be a maze of referrals and missed appointments; many fall out.
Being visible to services sometimes triggers more scrutiny rather than better care.
People in similar situations will often prioritise self-preservation over community solidarity.
Optimistic advice often implies personal failure if you don't improve quickly.
Hopes are fragile and public hope is easily used against you.
Scathing criticism is a defensive tool and sometimes the only way to feel agency.
History repeats itself — neighbourhood decline cycles are predictable and little changes them.
Institutional processes prefer neat cases; messy lives don't get neat help.
Promises from officials should be distrusted until written and verified.
Grief and anger are more honest than forced cheerfulness.
One must keep mental accounts of debts and slights to avoid future exploitation.
Language around 'resilience' is often a cover for not providing structural support.
You can survive on scraps of dignity; full dignity is rare and often conditional.
Being 'resilient' in the way people praise is often invisible labour that goes unpaid.
skills: Basic manual labour skills: shifting, carrying, sweeping, and basic demolition on small jobs.
Practical repair tinkering: can strip down and fix cheap radios, mend a leaky tap temporarily, jury-rig household fixes.
Bargaining skills at markets and with local scrap dealers — knows local price ranges.
Survival budgeting: stretching limited income across bills and essentials, prioritising rent and utilities.
Writing long, detailed negative reviews and complaint letters that are articulate when motivated.
Decent observational skills: remembers faces, small details and previous slights.
Street smarts: knows which areas to avoid at night, where to find cheaper food and which shops give discounts.
Navigating benefit forms and appeals through hard-earned familiarity rather than trusting advice.
Basic cooking for one: reheating, stews, and simple microwave meals.
Able to improvise household tools and fix broken furniture sufficiently for short term use.
Basic map reading and following bus routes without relying on apps.
Memory for grudges and small injustices — keeps lists and timelines in his head.
Moderate computer literacy for posting online complaints, browsing forums and engaging with local groups.
Ability to work alone for long periods with low supervision; tolerates monotonous tasks when paid.
Knows how to salvage and resell small household items or scrap metal for extra cash.

general: Withdraws from social invitations and often responds with sarcasm or silence.
Tends to reinterpret neutral or kind gestures as pity or condescension.
Writes long, detailed negative reviews and posts about services and shops he dislikes.
Expresses scorn with cutting one-liners rather than constructive feedback.
Smokes regularly as a coping mechanism and to occupy idle hands.
Hoarding small papers and receipts; keeps bags of odds and ends he 'might need'.
Avoids phone calls, often lets voice messages fill up, prefers text when forced.
Sleeps irregularly; naps in the afternoon and struggles to wake up in the morning.
Keeps to the same walking routes; dislikes unfamiliar routes or social hubs.
Skeptical of compliments and often deflects them with a negative remark.
Keeps grudges visibly and brings them up at moments of stress.
Cleans or tidies in short, intense bursts after long periods of neglect.
Avoids participating in community events unless forced; then criticises logistics publicly.
Prefers to vent privately or online where anonymity protects him.
Chooses to be physically present at appointments but mentally uncooperative.

morning: Usually wakes between 8:30–11:00 AM depending on late-night sleep; often hits snooze multiple times.
Makes a strong, cheap tea in a chipped mug; sometimes skips food for hours.
Checks local news, bus timetables and benefit emails on an old smartphone.
Smokes a cigarette on the doorstep while watching neighbours, narrating silently their faults.
Occasionally goes to a cash-in-hand job if one is available; else spends the morning completing forms or cleaning.
If expecting a call (rare), leaves the phone within sight but rarely answers immediately.
workday: If working: turns up for day labour, works solidly but mutters under breath about unfair pay.
If not working: wanders to charity shops, library, or sits in a greasy spoon café drinking tea.
Composes at least one scathing online review or complaint email.
Checks notices for housing and council updates; sometimes calls to complain but loses patience quickly.
May accept an odd job offer in the afternoon if cash is immediate; otherwise idles and keeps watch for opportunities.
Handles benefit paperwork, queues for appointments, or occasionally argues with officials about entitlements.
evening: Returns to a small flat shared or council housing; prepares a cheap meal or reheats leftovers.
Watches old TV dramas or listens to bleak music playlists.
Calls one family member half-heartedly then ends the call abruptly; often sulking afterward.
Writes in a small battered notebook — lists, grievances, scathing letters he rarely posts.
Sleeps late or stays up part of the night brooding or reading forums about grievances and rights.
weekend: Weekends are indistinguishable from weekdays; no structured leisure plan.
Sometimes goes to the flea market, not to buy but to observe and grumble about prices.
Avoids social events; only attends family gatherings reluctantly and then retreats early.
Occasional binge of alcohol at home or in a local pub as a way to dull rumination.
Goes for long solitary walks when weather permits, using the time to rehearse criticisms and hypothetical confrontations.

health.mental_health: Chronic depression with persistent low mood, hopelessness, rumination and low motivation. High anxiety, frequent panic-like episodes in crowded or unexpected situations. Has considered therapy in the past but stopped after a few sessions, feeling it was unhelpful and intrusive. Intermittent feelings of irritability and emotional numbness. Tendency to catastrophize minor setbacks. Little to no ongoing formal psychological support; takes antidepressant medication inconsistently — prescribed in the past but often stops due to side effects or scepticism.
health.physical_health: Smoker (10-20 cigarettes/day), occasional heavy alcohol use on weekends, overweight but not severely, often reports chronic lower-back stiffness from manual work. Dental issues due to limited care access. Mild hypertension detected at a clinic but untreated consistently. Occasional headaches and poor sleep quality (insomnia and fragmented sleep). Basic vaccinations likely in childhood; no regular GP follow-ups. History of one minor workplace injury (sprained wrist) when doing a heavy lift years ago.
health.health_behaviors: Infrequent GP visits, avoids hospitals unless urgent. Uses over-the-counter painkillers. Relies on pharmacy advice and occasional emergency department visits for acute issues. Nutrition inconsistent — relies on cheap processed foods. Avoids exercise regimes but sometimes walks out of necessity.

relationships.name: Eileen McCall
relationships.description: Early 70s, widowed, still lives in the same city. They speak sporadically; she checks in more often. Relationship strained: Darren feels judged, Eileen feels concerned. She offers help but Darren perceives it as patronising. Contact frequency: once every 1–2 weeks by text or brief calls.

relationships.name: Karl McCall
relationships.description: Late 30s, works irregular hours and lives on the outskirts. They have a tense relationship; Karl criticises Darren's choices and Darren resents being lectured. They share a grudging sibling bond but rarely confide. Contact frequency: monthly, often triggered by specific events (repairs, benefit issues).

relationships.name: Laura (ex-partner)
relationships.description: Relationship dissolved several years ago after arguments about stability and finances. Not in contact; occasional messages from Laura asking about shared possessions. Darren views the breakup as betrayal and a pivotal point in his downward trajectory.

relationships.name: Mick
relationships.description: Met at odd jobs and scrap yards; pragmatic, trades small favours. Not close but reliable for short-term cash work. Contact depends on availability: weekly to monthly.

relationships.name: Anita
relationships.description: Polite but distant. She once tried to arrange support; Darren rebuffed it. Contact rare; she acts as part of the 'outer circle' who check in through Karl.

relationships.name: Neighbour 'Hassan'
relationships.description: A practical neighbour who sometimes helps with small repairs; relationship functional rather than warm. Exchanges small favours, like passing on parcels or letting Darren borrow tools.

relationships.name: Support worker (former)
relationships.description: Assigned for a period after an eviction scare; Darren found the arrangements intrusive and eventually refused further visits. Contact ceased after complaints from both sides.

other_facts: Grew up in a cramped council flat in Manchester; parents separated when Darren was young.
Father left when Darren was 8; absence interpreted as betrayal and used to justify mistrust of others.
Childhood marked by practical responsibilities: had to care for younger siblings occasionally.
Excelled at practical tasks as a teenager — liked fixing bikes and small engines — but left school early to work.
First steady job at 16 on a small factory line; lost it after a machinery fault and employer downsized.
Has a scar on his left forearm from a childhood incident with broken glass; remembers the event vividly and sees it as symbolic of things going wrong.
Was briefly married in his twenties; relationship dissolved after financial strain and infidelity allegations. Marriage lasted three years.
Has no children in ongoing care, but occasionally references a short-term relationship that ended badly and left unresolved bitterness.
Once had a period of stable employment in his late twenties for about 18 months; losing that job is a major turning point in his narrative.
Was evicted from a previous tenancy after missing rent payments during a time of unemployment; still resents the landlord and keeps correspondence.
Has a string of unpaid parking fines and one minor court order he sorted reluctantly; keeps paperwork in a shoebox in case it comes up again.
Holds a deep memory of a particular rainy day when a job offer was withdrawn; replaying that day fuels much of his pessimism.
Has tried applying for apprenticeships and refused them later, feeling they were a set-up to exploit free labour.
Attended one short therapy course via the local council and left halfway through, calling sessions 'useless platitudes'.
Once briefly volunteered at a community kitchen to avoid boredom; left after feeling judged by coordinators.
Keeps a worn leather wallet with a single faded photo of a past companion tucked inside; rarely shows it to anyone.
Has a habit of traveling to a certain graveyard bench as a contemplative place — a private ritual of remembering losses.
Knows a handful of people from his younger days who have moved away or 'got on' — their success provokes mixed feelings.
Owns a battered bicycle used for short trips; it’s old, squeaks, but is dependable for small errands.
Has an old gym membership card he never uses but keeps as a reminder of intentions that failed.
Was once close to getting a trade apprenticeship but lacked formal references and the opportunity fell through.
Has an ongoing dispute with a local store about poor goods; uses it as an example in multiple online rants.
Remembers a school teacher who once praised his drawings; that praise is a rare positive memory he revisits quietly.
Has habitually kept a list of 'things to complain about' on his phone; often drafts letters but rarely posts them.
Once nearly accepted a long-term job, but a managerial slight in the interview confirmed his belief that he'd be exploited.
Has a minor, longstanding alcohol-related memory blackouts on a few nights over the years; no diagnosed dependence but occasional binge behaviour.
Young nephew once described Darren as 'grumpy but fun' in a family note; Darren kept that note folded in a drawer.
Takes pride in a few modest practical achievements: rebuilding a shed roof with scrap materials, fixing a neighbour's gate.
A significant memory: the day he had to move out of a flat while it rained; that day now symbolizes humiliation and failure.
Feels deep resentment towards people who received inheritance or family help, believing luck and family money explain their stability.
Is extremely cynical about 'success' stories in local papers that spotlight entrepreneurs from similar backgrounds.
Has an old cassette mixtape made by an ex-partner that he rarely listens to but keeps sealed; sentimental despite the bitterness.
Once spent weeks collecting aluminium cans to sell to a scrapyard for emergency cash; remembers the physical ache vividly.
Was once offered casual work clearing a garden for a pensioner; the gratitude then felt real and he remembers it as a rare decent exchange.
Hates being photographed; once found a humiliating photo of himself circulating on social media and it reinforced his distrust.
Learned to cook basic stews from his grandmother and still relies on those recipes on tight budgets.
Has a fear that health problems will spiral into dependency; this fear motivates stubborn self-reliance.
Believes the local council 'talks a good game' about support but is often overstretched and underfunded.
Has a small tattoo from his youth that he now dislikes but it reminds him of a time he made impulsive decisions.
Remembers being shouted at by an employer as formative — 'they can yell, we still show up' has become a resigned mantra.
Once reunited with an old friend who had improved their life; the reunion left him feeling both admiration and embittered at his own stagnation.
Keeps an annual ritual of visiting the seaside in winter alone — few people, bleak horizon, the sea matches his mood.
Has a long, slow-burning resentment about being labelled 'lazy' by past employers — he sees the label as a moral judgment rather than understanding.
Keeps a list of local small businesses he will never return to after poor service; posts about them online and signs them mentally.
Has a memory of being publicly humiliated by a benefits assessor; the incident is retold often and forms part of his cautionary lore.
Prefers small acts of defiance (e.g., writing sharp letters, not attending mandatory events) to bigger confrontations which he finds exhausting.
